chapter.htmlHeader: How should I assess a person with suspected dry eye syndrome?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
Take a history asking about:

  • Clinical features such as irritation, tearing, dryness, blurring of vision, and redness.
  • Symptom onset, duration, and fluctuation over time.
  • Exacerbating factors such as weather conditions (for example wind), decreased humidity, or situations where blink rate may be reduced for example with reading or computer use.
  • Ocular history, including:
    • Topical medications such as artificial tears, antihistamines, glaucoma medications, corticosteroids, homeopathic or herbal preparations.
    • Contact lens use.
    • Previous ocular surgery, for example, refractive surgery, entropion or ectropion repair, and cataract surgery.
    • Ocular conditions such as blepharitis, conjunctivitis, herpes simplex or varicella zoster virus, and ocular mucous membrane pemphigoid.
  • Red flags — more serious causes of symptoms may present with an acute history, persistent or profound visual loss, associated diplopia, or systemic features such as weight loss or fever. For further information, see the CKS topic on Red eye.
  • Past medical history of conditions associated with dry eye such as rosacea, psoriasis, atopy, Sjögren's syndrome, rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, menopause, lymphoma, chronic viral infections (for example HIV and hepatitis C), orbital radiation and neurological conditions (for example Parkinson disease or Bell’s palsy).
  • Associated features indicative of an undiagnosed underlying condition such as dry mouth, dental cavities, oral ulcers, fatigue, joint or muscle pain.
  • Systemic medications associated with dry eye such as retinoids, oral contraception, hormone replacement therapy, beta-blockers, anticholinergics, diuretics, antihistamines, antidepressants, and isotretinoin.
  • Trauma to the eye area.
  • Social history including smoking, alcohol, and occupation.

Examine the person, checking:

  • Visual acuity – visual acuity should not be severely impaired with dry eye syndrome.
  • For clinical signs of dry eye syndrome such as mild conjunctival redness – in many cases the eye examination is normal.
  • The pupils – abnormalities such as an irregular pupil may indicate an alternative serious cause such as uveitis.
  • The eyelids and lashes:
    • Look for incomplete closure or malposition of eyelids which can occur with proptosis, ectropion, or entropion.
    • Evert and inspect the eyelids – look for inflammation, abnormal deposits or secretions and signs of other causes of symptoms such as conjunctivitis and blepharitis. For further information, see the CKS topics on Conjunctivitis - allergic, Conjunctivitis - infective and Blepharitis.
  • The cornea and conjunctiva — abnormalities may indicate an alternative serious cause such as corneal ulcer or keratoconjunctivitis.
  • For signs of associated conditions such as rosacea, acne, seborrhoeic dermatitis, rheumatoid arthritis, Sjogren’s syndrome, systemic lupus erythematosus, Raynaud’s phenomenon, thyroid eye disease, Bell’s palsy or Parkinson’s disease.

Investigations

  • Slit lamp examination of the cornea and tear film in addition to investigations such as Schirmer’s test are needed for a formal diagnosis of dry eye syndrome. The equipment and expertise for these tests are not commonly available in primary care and referral to an optometrist or ophthalmologist is usually required.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on assessment of a person with suspected dry eye syndrome are based on the clinical guidelines National dry eye disease guidelines for Canadian optometrists. Screening, diagnosis and management of dry eye disease: practical guidelines for Canadian optometrists [Prokopich, 2014], Dry eye (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) [College of Optometrists, 2015] and Summary benchmarks for Preferred Practice Pattern guidelines [American Academy of Ophthalmology, 2016] and expert opinion in review articles [Tong, 2012b; Bartlett, 2015; Messmer, 2015; BMJ Best Practice, 2016; Milner, 2017].

Symptoms and signs

  • Expert opinion in a review article is that the clinical picture of dry eye disease is complicated by the poor correlation between symptoms and signs and severity [Bartlett, 2015].

Exacerbating factors

  • Exogenous irritants and allergens are not thought to cause dry eye but may exacerbate symptoms [American Academy of Ophthalmology, 2013].
  • Worsening of symptoms with prolonged visual tasks, exposure to wind and air conditioning is strongly suggestive dry eye [Tong, 2012b].

Associated features

  • The presence of additional features, such as dry mouth, in people with dry eyes should prompt consideration of underlying systemic conditions (such as Sjogren’s syndrome) which require referral to secondary care [Prokopich, 2014].

Investigations

  • No single test is adequate for establishing the diagnosis of dry eye — specialist equipment is needed for definitive diagnosis [Tong, 2012b; American Academy of Ophthalmology, 2013; Prokopich, 2014; BMJ Best Practice, 2016].
